title: Problem Overview
content: This header documents **Erdős Problem #229** about prescribing zeros of derivatives of entire functions. Given discrete sets (Sₙ), can we find a transcendental entire function whose derivatives vanish on them? Answer: YES.
mathContext: The problem combines complex analysis (entire functions, derivatives) with topology (discrete sets). The solution by Barth-Schneider (1972) shows the answer is yes.

title: No Finite Limit Point
content: A set has **no finite limit point** if its derived set (set of accumulation points) is empty. This means the set is discrete - every point is isolated from the others.
mathContext: HasNoFiniteLimitPoint S := derivedSet S = ∅. This is the standard condition for prescribing zeros of analytic functions, forced by the identity theorem.

title: Entire Function
content: A function ℂ → ℂ is **entire** if it is differentiable (holomorphic) at every point in the complex plane. Examples: eᶻ, sin(z), polynomials.
mathContext: IsEntireFunction f := Differentiable ℂ f. This means f has a complex derivative at every point, equivalently it's analytic everywhere.

title: Transcendental Function
content: A **transcendental** entire function is one that is not a polynomial. It has infinitely many non-zero derivatives. Examples: eᶻ, sin(z), cos(z).
mathContext: IsTranscendental f := IsEntireFunction f ∧ ¬∃ p : Polynomial ℂ, f = p.eval. The 'transcendental' condition ensures we're not just dealing with finite-degree polynomials.

title: The Main Question
content: **Erdős Problem #229**: Given discrete sets (Sₙ), can we find a transcendental entire function f and indices kₙ such that f^(kₙ) vanishes on Sₙ for all n?
mathContext: Erdos229Question := ∀ S, (∀ n, HasNoFiniteLimitPoint (S n)) → ∃ f, IsTranscendental f ∧ ∀ n ≥ 1, ∃ k, ∀ z ∈ S n, iteratedDeriv k f z = 0.

title: Why Discrete Sets?
content: The **identity theorem** says that if an analytic function has zeros with a limit point, it must be identically zero. Therefore, we can only prescribe zeros on discrete sets.
mathContext: This axiom states that discrete sets are either empty or countable. The discreteness is essential - it's why the Sₙ must have no finite limit points.

title: Barth-Schneider Theorem
content: **Theorem** (Barth-Schneider, 1972): The answer to Erdős Problem #229 is YES. For any sequence of discrete sets, there exists a transcendental entire function whose derivatives vanish on them.
mathContext: axiom barth_schneider_theorem : Erdos229Question. The construction uses Weierstrass products and careful control of derivatives. Axiomatized because the proof requires advanced function theory.

title: The Answer
content: The answer to Erdős Problem #229 is **YES**: we can always find such a transcendental entire function.
mathContext: theorem erdos_229_answer : Erdos229Question := barth_schneider_theorem. This directly invokes the axiomatized Barth-Schneider result.

title: Explicit Formulation
content: An equivalent formulation: for any sequence of discrete sets, there exist a transcendental entire function f and a sequence of **positive** integers (nₖ) such that f^(nₖ) vanishes on Sₖ.
mathContext: This makes explicit that the derivative indices nₖ are positive, not just non-negative. The function f and the sequence (nₖ) are constructed together.

title: Weierstrass Factorization
content: The **Weierstrass factorization theorem** is a classical result: for any discrete set S, there exists an entire function vanishing exactly on S. This is a special case (k = 0) of the general result.
mathContext: axiom weierstrass_factorization : ∀ S, HasNoFiniteLimitPoint S → ∃ f, IsEntireFunction f ∧ ∀ z ∈ S, f z = 0. This classical theorem is the foundation for prescribing zeros.

title: Derivative Zeros
content: We can also prescribe zeros of a **specific** derivative: given k and a discrete set S, there exists an entire function whose k-th derivative vanishes on S.
mathContext: axiom derivative_zeros : ∀ k, ∀ S, HasNoFiniteLimitPoint S → ∃ f, IsEntireFunction f ∧ ∀ z ∈ S, iteratedDeriv k f z = 0. This extends Weierstrass to derivatives.

title: Summary
content: The **summary** confirms the main result: Erdős Problem #229 has a positive answer via the Barth-Schneider theorem.
mathContext: theorem summary_erdos_229 : Erdos229Question := barth_schneider_theorem. This packages the key result for export.
